text: you've probably heard people say that if
your mother's father was bald you're
more likely to lose those beautiful
locks of hair down the road but what
truth is there to this it turns out that
one of the major contributors to hair
loss is Sex Link humans have 46
chromosomes of DNA of which two help to
determine your sex the X and the Y
chromosome if you're a female you have
two X chromosomes but if you're a male
you have an X and A Y chromosome studies
show that the most influential hair loss
Gene is located on the X chromosome only
what does this mean well if you're a
male you get an X chromosome from your
mother but must receive a y chromosome
from your father because if you got your
father's X chromosome you'd be a female
so if one of your mother's ex
chromosomes has this hair loss Gene you
have a 50/50 chance of getting it from
her in this way hair loss is partially
hereditary and pass through the maternal
side for males females on the other hand
must get two copies of this Gene one on
each X chromosome in order to physically
express it so if your mother does
Express these traits it means she will
be passing an affected chromosome to you
but why do we say to look at your
mother's father well if he has visible
male pattern baldness then your mother
has at least one copy of the affected X
chromosome from him because in order to
have a daughter he must have passed on
his X chromosome not his y the thing to
note here is that this is just one of
the contributors to hair loss and while
it's thought to be the most significant
many Studies have found other hair LED
genes which aren't sexlink at all
including some on the Y chromosome
meaning they can be transferred from
both the mother and the father on top of
this some Studies have shown
correlations between age exercise
nutrition and even stress levels so
while a quick check of your mom's dad's
hair maybe an indicator for future hair
loss A headful of hair on Grandpa's head
doesn't guarantee you're in the clear
got a burning question you want answered
ask it in the comments or on Facebook
and Twitter and subscribe for more
weekly science videos
[Music]
